Description: Rim sherd of South Ionian pottery little-master cup; creeam slip, glaze fired mid-brown; interior: traces of dilute lines between bands; top of lip glazed; exterior: myrtle leaf frieze.
Curator's comments: Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd and the junction of the rim and body is impossible to determine, the sherd likely belongs with his Little Master Ionian Cups and either his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9B, which also coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) or Ionian Cups Type 9C. This type finds parallels with the shape of Attic Little Master lip cups. These cups have been found in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Probably from same cup as 1888,0601.409 and 1965,0930.651, although the width of some bands is not uniform on the three.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.789) (Phase 3)
